format among surveys The aim study describe predictors cervical cancer screening older women reported three national surveys   Methods  The Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System BRFSS 2016 Health Information National Trends Survey HINTS 2017 Health Center Patient Survey HCPS 2014 analyzed univariate multivariate analyses We defined cohort women without hysterectomy 45 65 years old The primary outcome cytology within last 3 years   Results  Overall Pap screening rates 71 BRFSS 79 HINTS 66 HCPS among 41 657 740 1571 women respectively BRFSS showed women 60 64 years old aPR 0 88 95 CI 0 85 0 screening aPR 1 20 95 CI 1 13 1 28 insurance higher screening rates uninsured aPR 1 47 95 CI 1 33 1 62 HINTS HCPS also showed trends   Conclusions  All three surveys show cervical cancer screening rates women 45 65 years insufficient reduce cervical cancer incidence Insurance major positive predictor screening followed younger age education Race ethnicity variable predictors depending survey sustainability immunization registries   Abstract   Introduction  The Global Vaccine Action Plan Regional Immunization Action Plan Americas call countries improve immunization data quality Immunization information systems particularly electronic immunization registries EIRs help facilitate program management increase coverage However little known efforts develop implement systems low middle income countries We present experiences Mexico Peru implementing EIRs   Methods  We conducted case studies EIR Mexico population registry Peru Information gathered technical documents stakeholder focus groups site visits semi structured interviews national stakeholders We organized findings narratives emphasized challenges lessons learned   Results  Mexico built one world first EIRs incorporating novel features local level tracking patients however insufficient resources poor data registration practices led system discontinuation Peru created information system improve affiliation social programs including immunization program quality demographic data Mexico experience highlights lessons failed sustainability EIR laudable effort reform country information system Peru demonstrates attempts improve health data may strengthen health systems including immunization data Major challenges information system implementation sustainability Peru Mexico related funding clear governance structures resistance among health workers   Discussion  These case studies reinforce need countries ensure adequate funding plans sustainability health worker capacity building activities implementing EIRs They also suggest new approaches implementation including economic incentives sub national administrative levels opportunities link efforts improve immunization data health political priorities More information best practices needed ensure successful adoption sustainability immunization registries low middle income countries   Keywords   Electronic immunization interviews Information coded short phrases codes grouped identify main factors affecting information systems Mexico Peru   3  Results   3 1  Mexico   3 1 1  Health system National immunization program  In 1973 Mexico established NIP 1991 became Universal Vaccination Program PVU   4  All acronyms public agencies Mexico Peru provided Spanish e g PVU  Programa Universal de Vacunación   3 1 2  Immunization information system  In 1991 Mexico established PROVAC computerized program record immunization data country health facilities including private facilities  Though official coverage rates high time concerns levels might falsely elevated During system 18 year history Mexico developed different versions PROVAC program open source changes required include eight vaccines added PVU 1991 2008  In 2013 Mexico stopped using PROVAC due coverage discrepancies The National Population Council CONAPO completed data reconciliation information National Institute Statistics Geography showed PROVAC denominators underestimated coverages thus overestimated Coverages estimated near 100 dropped around 80 e g 99 DTP3 2012 vs 83 DTP3 2013   3 1 3  Implementation challenges  PROVAC faced many challenges including accelerated inclusion new vaccines insufficient resources information technology personnel devoted system  PROVAC open coding exposed errors Between within regions users administrators created different versions system resulting inconsistencies potential data manipulation Complicating matters errors numerators denominators Denominators never validated CONAPO data numerators based distributed rather administered doses This resulted partly PROVAC design Although health workers linked administered doses patients local level system never online meaning coverage information higher levels based aggregated data prone substitute estimations e doses distributed rather doses administered   3 1 4  Lessons learned next steps  In 2013 Mexico acknowledged poor quality vaccination coverage estimates began revamp information system  Nevertheless transition difficult due challenges coordinating public private providers immunization services Mexico fragmented health system multiple providers health insurance mechanisms   3 2  Peru   3 2 1  Health system National immunization program  Peru established NIP 1979 Coverages generally high DTP3 88 95 2012 2016   3 2 2  The Padrón Nominal impact immunization data  In 2012 Peru created census database  Padrón Nominal  Three major political issues led PN creation The first longstanding problem citizens lacking representation civil registries  Developing PN required Peru evaluate birth registration practices Since 2004 ESNI used paper based registry linked MoH health target data census projections starting 2016 used birth registration systems calculate immunization coverage  To capture children without documentation MoH MEF MIDIS incentivized municipalities identify children aged 6 years areas collaboration health facilities civil registration offices The MEF required local governments capture users immunization services registries condition financing PN  From 2013 2016 incentives led widespread use  Padrón   3 2 3  Implementation challenges  Challenges implementing PN include reconciling discrepancies denominator data PN population figures vs census data difficulties connecting system nominal registries lack funding MEF 2016   3 2 4  Lessons learned next steps  Due aforementioned challenges PN remains incompletely implemented Even system capacity identify children lacking health social interventions generate useful data decision making suggests may become permanent policy tool  Padrón   4  Discussion  Extending benefits immunization people requires reliable timely immunization data  Padrón Nominal  Compared aspects NIPs low middle income countries EIRs may understudied underappreciated While sustainable funding health worker training key determinants EIR sustainability relatively little known low middle income countries sustain systems  First rationales establishing strengthening EIRs may extend beyond immunization health political priorities As immunization integrates health services governments likely support proposals multi purpose interventions The PN creation Peru supported least four governmental agencies exemplifies point Second EIR sustainability requires investment various government agencies investment might increased agency understands stands gain In Peru MEF sought better data planning purposes MoH sought higher coverages MIDIS sought equitable health outcomes In designing EIR proposals sustainability plans health officials thus consider system benefit stakeholders Third predictable funding necessary countries lacking funding likely delay implementation resources available ideally protected long term strategies clear governance structures budgets secured legislation Countries may consider innovative funding models economic incentives used Peru These models may facilitate implementation prove cost effective improve service quality  Finally EIR sustainability depends system quality adaptability Recommendations exist variables child age guiding principles entering data close vaccination possible terms time place  Several limitations acknowledged Case studies offer depth explanations complex events multiple causes criticized lacking rigor producing non generalizable results  To deliver benefits vaccination persons countries Americas WHO regions must continue improve immunization information systems molecular phylogeny shield bearer moth family Heliozelidae   Five major clades suggested molecular evidence   Rich undescribed species diversity prevalent southern hemisphere particularly Australia   Abstract   Heliozelidae widespread evolutionarily early diverging family small day flying monotrysian moths comprehensive phylogeny lacking We generated first molecular phylogeny family using DNA sequences two mitochondrial genes COI COII two nuclear genes H3 28S 130 Heliozelidae specimens including eight twelve known genera  Antispila  Antispilina  Coptodisca  Heliozela  Holocacista Abstract   BACKGROUND CONTEXT  Models predicting recovery traumatic spinal cord injury tSCI patients developed optimize care Several models predicting tSCI recovery previously validated yet recent findings question accuracy particularly patients whose prognoses least predictable   PURPOSE  To compare independent ambulatory outcomes AIS ASIA American Spinal Injury Association Impairment Scale A B C D patients well AIS B C AIS A D patients applying two existing logistic regression prediction models   STUDY DESIGN  A prospective cohort study   PARTICIPANT SAMPLE  Individuals tSCI enrolled pan Canadian Rick Hansen SCI Registry RHSCIR 2004 2016 complete neurologic examination Functional Independence Measure FIM outcome data   OUTCOME MEASURES  The FIM locomotor score used assess independent walking ability 1 year follow   METHODS  Two validated prediction models evaluated ability predict walking 1 year postinjury Relative prognostic performance compared area receiver operating curve AUC   RESULTS  In total 675 tSCI patients identified analysis In model 1 predictive accuracies 675 AIS A B C D patients measured AUC 0 730 95 confidence interval CI 0 622 0 838 0 691 0 533 0 849 0 850 0 771 0 928 0 516 0 320 0 711 respectively In 160 AIS B C patients model 1 generated AUC 0 833 95 CI 0 771 0 895 whereas model 2 generated AUC 0 821 95 CI 0 754 0 887 The AUC 515 AIS A D patients 0 954 95 CI 0 933 0 975 model 1 0 950 0 928 0 971 model 2 The difference prediction accuracy AIS B C cohort AIS A D cohort statistically significant using models p 00034 p 00038 The models statistically different individual subgroup analyses   CONCLUSIONS  Previously tested prediction models demonstrated lower predictive accuracy AIS B C AIS A D patients These models unable effectively prognosticate AIS A D patients separately failure masked amalgamating two patient populations This suggests former prediction models achieved strong prognostic accuracy combining AIS classifications coupled disproportionately high proportion AIS A D patients   Keywords   Functional outcomes   Logistic regression   Predictive accuracy   Prognosis   Walking   Traumatic spinal cord injury     Introduction  The burden traumatic spinal cord injury tSCI long recognized individual societal levels These injuries often lead irreversible motor sensory autonomic damage may compromise functional ability independent walking  The demand effective prognostication tSCI lent numerous studies evaluating recovery using prediction models Van Middendorp et al  Despite reported success recent prognostic models important note developed severities tSCI collective whole severe injuries AIS American Spinal Injury Association Impairment Scale A least severe injuries AIS D Hicks et al  Our hypothesis prognostication AIS B C patients less accurate AIS A D former models achieve high predictive accuracy means sampling bias As aim examine compare predictive accuracy van Middendorp et al   Methods   Analysis cohort  Participants study obtained RHSCIR 2004 2016 includes 18 acute care 13 rehabilitation hospitals across Canada The RHSCIR prospective observational registry created answer research questions facilitate implementation best practices Full details RHSCIR published elsewhere   Outcome measures  Neurologic severity ie AIS level injury time admission assessed within 15 days injury according International Standards Neurological Classification Spinal Cord Injury ISNCSCI   Prediction modeling  We applied five predictive variables RHSCIR database previously described van Middendorp et al   Results   Demographic injury details  The analysis cohort included 675 participants 210 31 1 AIS A 51 7 6 AIS B 109 16 1 AIS C 305 45 2 AIS D See   Prediction models  Prediction rule scores determine probabilities walking independently 1 year postinjury van Middendorp Hicks models calculated individually AIS classifications A B C D well AIS A D AIS B C subgroups Concordance matrices used assess degree agreement two variables found   Individual AIS classification prognostication  The overall classification accuracy sensitivity specificity AUCs generated tested models summarized  Using van Middendorp model AUCs AIS A B C D 0 730 0 622 0 838 0 691 0 533 0 849 0 850 0 771 0 928 0 516 0 320 0 711 respectively Using Hicks model AUC AIS A B C D 0 730 0 621 0 839 0 714 0 565 0 863 0 840 0 0 771 0 895 0 821 95 CI 0 754 0 887 respectively   Model comparisons  The difference AUC AIS A D AIS B C cohorts statistically significant using van Middendorp Hicks models p 00038 When comparing two models difference AUCs statistically significant AIS A D p 131 AIS B C p 448 The receiver operating characteristic ROC curves models comparing AIS A D AIS B C shown   Discussion  In study RHSCIR investigated utility two multivariable prediction models specific cohort AIS B C patients recovering tSCI The multinational validated five variable model proposed van Middendorp et al  Part bias related limitation ROC used diagnostic test Very high sensitivity specificity consequently high AUC values artificially obtained simply increasing sample size diagonal values concordance matrix  Applying currently established prediction models tested hypothesis prognostic capability tSCI prediction rules walking 1 year postinjury may compromised preponderant predictable nature AIS A walking unlikely AIS D walking likely patients Of recent prediction rules van Middendorp five variable prediction model garnered considerable international attention prognostic capability evaluated validated numerous studies  In addition differences subgroup analysis notable failure models prognosticate patients within individual AIS classifications This prominent reference individual AIS A AIS D populations Both models demonstrated poor sensitivity eg 37 2 van Middendorp model relatively low AUC AIS A effectively underestimating number patients would walk 1 year postinjury Although makes intuitive sense AIS A patients ie patients complete SCI would experience unfavorable ambulatory outcomes ability individuals experience significant functional outcomes supported literature  Although AUC common tool measure predictive accuracy binary classification system  Despite proposal Hicks et al  Strengths study include scope centers covered RHSCIR providing good representation true tSCI patient population national level Furthermore first paper highlighting clinically critical shortcomings validated prediction models  This study limitations Using binary outcome walking vs walking simulate independent ambulatory functions fixed time point 1 year postinjury opposed continuous outcome eg ambulatory improvements extended time period may truly indicative patient recovery Further van Middendorp model analyzed outcome using Spinal Cord Independence Measure whereas Hicks model used FIM However dichotomizing outcome walking versus walking reduces subtleties difference two measures Additionally study relatively limited sample size owing difficulty extracting complete patient data neurologic sensory scores multicenter database Further AIS B C least common tSCI result led small sample size Last given RHSCIR subject response rates participant willingness sample population may entirely representative true patient population results validated SCI datasets   Conclusions  This study demonstrates limited accuracy validated models prognostication walking AIS B C patients contrast AIS A D patients It also underlines inability models prognosticate patients within given AIS classification eg AIS A AIS D individually This highlights possible misperception former publications prediction models high equivalent prediction accuracies AIS classes In light findings may beneficial future prediction models incorporate additional relevant variables use advanced analytical methodologies including artificial intelligence   Acknowledgments  Data research collected using
